subject: Cooking
title: Why Onions Make You Cry
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Why Onions Make You Cry.

hook.text: You slice an onion and within seconds, tears stream down your face. It's chemical warfare.

buildup.text: Cutting ruptures onion cells, releasing enzymes that convert sulfur compounds into a volatile gas.

discovery.text: That gas â€” syn-propanethial-S-oxide â€” reacts with moisture in your eyes to form sulfuric acid.

twist.text: Chilling onions slows the enzyme reaction, producing less gas and fewer tears.

climax.text: Japanese scientists bred 'tearless' onions by silencing the gene for the lachrymatory enzyme.

punchline.text: Onions evolved tear gas as a defense. We eat them anyway.
